p: Both the structural and non-structural proteins of CHIKV have been reported to contain B-cell epitopes. However, E2 and (to a lesser extent) nsP3 contain the epitopes most frequently targeted by antibodies from infected individuals [ 22]. Although CHIKV E1 is located on the viral surface, there are few examples of neutralizing antibodies that target E1 [ 22, 23]. Studies of alphaviruses have indicated that the recognition of the E1 protein by monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) depends on several conditions, including the dissociation of the E2-E1 heterodimer [ 24, 25] or the exposure of virions to low pH [ 26]. To date, mouse anti-CHIKV E1 antibodies have been generated and employed primarily in the context of immunodiagnostic test development [ 23, 27, 28].
